I am to assist families in reducing tensions during adolescence adolescence is a time that is difficult for both parents and youngsters a Time filled with challenges and decisions concerning problems ranging from what clothes to wear to handling the pressure to use drugs learning how to make those decisions is part of the growing up process everyone faces making good responsible decisions however is not inevitable it's an acquired skill like other skills it is
one best learned with the help of someone more experienced nasby believes that help comes most logically from parents and begins with good family communication

to help parents and their youngsters through this time nasby has developed two booklets helping youth decide and helping youth say no the booklets are designed for use by parents to help young people deal with peer pressure and learn to make responsible decisions

it's easy for a team to say no when he or she is in an auditorium surrounded by chanting students but youngsters face peer pressure as a constant part of their daily lives adults can help them learn how to handle those pressures helping youth say no debuted before a national audience in April 1987

ation and let the adult play the child and the child played the adult see what happens you learn a lot about yourself there are a variety of ways that you can start your child talking but the important thing is to be interested in what the child is interested in well parents have to know their children pretty well to know the answers to that and according to your booklets parents probably know a great deal less about their kids than they think they do it's amazing in

to tell us about it welcome to Noonday jar program I'd like for all people watching who know a teenager or even better yet who are parents of a teenager to pay special attention to this segment because we have what I feel to be very valuable information for anyone who knows a teenager we're going to talk about how to help teenagers now we all know about the school assemblies where everyone says just say no and everyone gets excited but unfortunately the situation can be quite different when a teenager is placed in a social situation and has to deal with peer pressure

he said that program such as this just simply won't make a dent in helping our young people to say no to drugs unless we take the drugs out of the situation she called it a Band-Aid I think and and I understand where he's coming from and I think that's why with our booklet helping you say no we're trying to assist parents in dealing with their children coping with all of peer pressure of which drugs is one part

make one feel not so helpless and will they come away for after reading the pain I think so I think so the book does several things one thing it does is it gives some information about peer pressure and the different types of peer pressure what to watch out for it also gives some guides that parents can use as far as working with their young person developing love and understanding and patience and then probably one of the most important things it does is offer some actual techniques that they can practice with their young people too

teach them how to say no to visualize so that they have some Alternatives you know we're all better were more successful if we're better prepared in any situation and young people need that guidance helping youth say no a very good book news articles about the program further spread the word appearing in over 700 Community newspapers read by nearly 6 million people Nationwide letters to nasby from hundreds of parents ministers teachers and young people
testified to the impact of the program materials

the program has continued to grow evolving into a community-based alliance between families schools businesses and Civic groups nasby is working right now with 22 communities across the country to increase understanding between parents and teens to help them talk more easily and effectively with each other and to make responsible decisions together

each year several communities are chosen through a national selection process to participate in Naz bees Community Alliance project selected communities receive a seed Grant to help in establishing their local programs Community representatives are offered training in how to plan and conduct a Community Alliance project how to develop Community Support how to interest the media and how to use the helping youth decide materials the communities will also receive
building materials and ongoing technical assistance from the National Association of state boards of Education

for further information concerning the Community Alliance program contact Community Alliance program director National Association of state boards of Education 1012 Cameron Street Alexandria Virginia to 2314
